Today China wants to modernize its force.
It also wants to calm other countries worried about big increases in China's defense spending.
So to accomplish those dueling goals, China did something unusual.
It invited foreign journalists to a People's Liberation Army base.
NPR's Anthony Kuhn was there and filed this report.
(Soundbite of ceremony)
Infantry Brigade 196 is one of the PLA units tasked with defending China's capital.
China's growing defense budget has helped build new barracks and training facilities for the unit's 3,500 troops.
Senior Colonel Zhang Qingjiang is the brigade's commander.
(Through translator) We've seen improvements in three areas.
Our salaries have gone up.
They've doubled.
Our daily food allowances have increased by one yuan this year.
And our equipment has gradually been upgraded.
Our Type 95 assault rifles, for example, are the newest models.
(Soundbite of weapons firing)
The troops shoot at metal targets with rifles that are newer and lighter than the old AK-47s that the PLA has used for much of the past half century.
Colonel Zhang says the brigade is also testing navigation and positioning devices for the Beidou or Big Dipper satellite system that China is rolling out.
But instead of showing foreign journalists the high-tech gear, the brigade scrambles its artillery and machine gun troops to hit targets down range.
Then the brigade's reconnaissance scouts put on a choreographed kung fu show.
(Soundbite of kung fu show)
China's published military budget for this year is almost $45 billion, up nearly 18 percent over last year.
That's the biggest defense budget in Asia, but it's less than 10 percent of the U.S.'s published defense budget.
When asked at a briefing what country might threaten China and justify all of the spending, Colonel Zhang answers diplomatically.
(Through translator) We train to counter possible military scenarios, doctrines and weapon systems.
We don't think that preparing to fight future wars requires training against specific adversaries.
The PLA is the world's largest army, with 2.3 million members.
And China points out that it spends about 147th of what the U.S.
spends on each soldier.
In the mess hall, a wiry 20-year-old conscript named Lee Pung(ph) helps himself to a plate of stir-fried vegetables, rice, corn on the cob and soup.
There's not much meat.
Private Lee gets paid the equivalent of about $32 a month.
He says he'll serve out his two years and then quit.
(Chinese spoken)
Government policies towards soldiers are pretty supportive these days, he says.
I'm sure that when I get out of the service the local government will arrange a decent job for me.
In recent years, China has taken a number of moves to make the PLA more professional.
It's built its own ROTC program to recruit better-educated officers.
It ordered the PLA to divest its extensive business holdings.
And it has also reduced the number of political indoctrination classes.
But a main theme of today's anniversary is that the ruling communist party will not allow the PLA to become too depoliticized.
The party, after all, founded the PLA amid civil war in 1927.
And Defense Minister Cao Gangchuan wrote in a recent article that suggestions that the government take over the PLA from the party are tantamount to subversion.
Anthony Kuhn, NPR News, Beijing.
